unnormalised: Someone asked me about property rates in Bangalore recently, so I thought I’d share some insights. Honestly, it’s a bit all over the place! You can find apartments in Whitefield starting from around Rs. 5000 per sq ft, but then in Koramangala, expect to pay upwards of Rs. 12000/sq ft. Location is key, bhai. Amenities also play a HUGE role in pricing. Think clubhouse, swimming pool, security…all that jazz.
normalised: Someone asked me about property rates in Bangalore recently, so I thought I’d share some insights. Honestly, it’s a bit all over the place! You can find apartments in Whitefield starting from around rupees five thousand per square foot, but then in Koramangala, expect to pay upwards of rupees twelve thousand per square foot. Location is key, bhai. Amenities also play a H-U-G-E role in pricing. Think clubhouse, swimming pool, security…all that jazz.

unnormalised: Then you’ve got the whole builder reputation thing. A property by Prestige or Sobha will obviously cost more than one by a less known builder. Also, plot sizes matter if you are going for a house. A 30x40 site might cost you around Rs. 80 lakhs in a developing area, but a similar plot in a prime location like Jayanagar could easily be Rs. 2 crores or more. And don't forget registration charges, usually around 1% of the property value + stamp duty.
normalised: Then you’ve got the whole builder reputation thing. A property by Prestige or Sobha will obviously cost more than one by a less known builder. Also, plot sizes matter if you are going for a house. A thirty by forty site might cost you around rupees eighty lakhs in a developing area, but a similar plot in a prime location like Jayanagar could easily be rupees two crores or more. And don't forget registration charges, usually around one percent of the property value plus stamp duty.

unnormalised: Honestly, navigating Bangalore real estate is a task and half! Best advice? Do your homework. Check property portals, talk to brokers, and most importantly, visit the sites yourself. Don’t blindly trust anything you read online. Also, be prepared to negotiate! Good luck finding your dream home!
normalised: Honestly, navigating Bangalore real estate is a task and a half! Best advice? Do your homework. Check property portals, talk to brokers, and most importantly, visit the sites yourself. Don’t blindly trust anything you read online. Also, be prepared to negotiate! Good luck finding your dream home!
